sn6.14:2.3: Sikhī means “halo” or “crown”. DN 14:1.12.4 says Aruṇa was his father, and Pabhāvatī his mother. The son of King Dawn and Queen Radiant in the City of the Dawn, Sikhī is the streaming rays of sunrise. These names recall a solar myth.
sn6.14:2.4: Abhibhū (“Victor”) and Sambhava (“son of Śambhu the blessed”) are also at DN 14:1.9.2. Śambhu is commonly found in the Rig Veda in the sense, “blessing, benefit”, and became a common name or epithet of gods, etc.
sn6.14:2.6: Gotama occasionally addresses a mendicant as brahmin, but only by way of special encouragement (eg. MN 86:17.6).
sn6.14:4.4: The Buddha understood that you do not have to always give the audience what they want.
sn6.14:4.5: This display is unique in the Suttas. It is referred to at Ps 3.2:15.2, which calls it “the power of transformation” (vikubbanā iddhi), for which see DN 18:22.3 and Thag 20.1:44.3.
sn6.14:5.3: Ānanda asks the Buddha about this at AN 3.80.
sn6.14:6.1: These verses are spoken by the otherwise unknown monk Abhibhūta at Thag 3.13. Perhaps there has been some confusion in the name.
